intro: Puelia coriacea, commonly known as rough pellitory, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Acanthaceae family and is characterized by its hairy, succulent stems and opposite, ovate leaves. The plant produces small, tubular flowers that are typically pink or purple, arranged in spikes at the ends of the branches. It thrives in moist, shaded environments and is often found in woodland areas. Puelia coriacea is known for its hardy nature and ability to tolerate partial shade, making it a common sight in the understory of forests.
